Dear Mr. McKeage:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was admitted to a new facility with 30 or more cuts on their
arm that varied in length and depth and were red. Youth was
taken to the hospital and required medication treatment due to the
cuts being infected.
Investigation Interviews:
The complainant was interviewed via telephone on January
30, 2023, and reported they had no further information.
2

Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, and again on February 22, 2023, via Teams,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Director reported Youth A
was discharged from Bay Pines Center on January 18, 2023 and
transported to another facility. Director described Youth A having
a long history of self-harming behavior by cutting his arm. Director
stated whenever Youth A would cut his arm staff would clean the
wound, complete a medical slip to be seen by the nurse or take
Youth A to the hospital for stitches. Director reported Youth A
would often refuse treatment and not take his medication to help
with the infection if the cuts were infected. Director stated Youth A
would tear out the stitches and rub toothpaste or deodorant in the
cuts.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, and again on February 22, 2023, via Teams,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Therapist stated Youth A
would use anything to cut his arm and refuse to have staff clean
the cuts. Therapist reported Nurse treated Youth A several times
by cleaning the wounds, putting ointment on the cuts, and
bandaging the arm. Therapist stated she took Youth A to the
hospital multiple times to get stitches.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on February
1, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Nurse described
Youth A being at the facility for about two years and cutting the
whole time. Nurse stated Youth A was treated several times at
Bay Pines and at the hospital. Nurse described staff completing a
medical slip for Youth A to be seen and Nurse examining the cuts.
Nurse reported anytime the wounds showed signs of being
infected Youth A would be prescribed Bactrim. Nurse stated
Youth A would often not follow through with taking the Bactrim,
refused to have the wounds cleaned, would dig at the wounds,
remove the stitches by biting at them and rubbed toothpaste in the
cuts which would make it difficult for the wounds to heal and not
get infected.
Group Leader was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Group
Leader stated Youth A cut frequently and would be taken to the
hospital for treatment. Group Leader reported Youth A would pull
the stitches out and often refuse to allow staff to clean the cuts.
Group Leader stated he was aware staff would frequently
complete medical slips to have Nurse look at Youth A’s cuts.
3

Youth A was interviewed via Teams on February 7, 2023.
Youth A reported while at Bay Pines Center, “staff watched me
more.” Youth A stated he was not sure why but guessed it was
because of him cutting. Youth A described staff telling him to stop
when he was self-harming but stated he would not stop cutting.
Youth A reported staff would clean his cuts and take him to get
stitches “every time I cut.” Youth A stated he would refuse to
allow staff to clean his cuts and not take medication if the cuts
were infected.
Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on February 17, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor stated Youth A
would often choose not to get stitches or would pull them out
when he did. Supervisor reported Youth A would rub deodorant or
toothpaste into the cuts, would refuse the antibiotic or allow staff
to clean the wounds. Supervisor stated he could only recall one
or two times the cuts were infected. Supervisor stated medical
slips were completed and staff would do their best to clean the
cuts or encourage Youth A to clean the cuts.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via Teams on February 17, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Therapist 2 stated Youth A
would receive treatment for his cutting but would often refuse to
allow staff to clean the cuts. Therapist 2 reported when Youth A
did get stitches, he would rip them out.
DHHS Worker has no findings in the investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
The following documents were reviewed for Youth A from
August 2022 – January 18, 2023. There were multiple
documents from numerous dates during this time frame that
were reviewed.
• Bay Pines Center Health Service Requests completed by
Bay Pines staff requesting Youth A’s cuts to be examined
by Nurse.
• OSF HealthCare office visit notes no mention of infections.
Common language found in the reports: “no erythema,
edema or drainage noted. No concerns for secondary skin
infection at this time, no active drainage or lymphatic
streaking.”
• OSF Walk in Clinic, common language found in the reports:
“sutures were placed, five days ago he chewed the sutures
out with his teeth, staff was concerned he could possibly
have skin infection, surrounding skin is clean, dry and
intact, patient states he was trying to bite the meat.”
4

• Staff Shift Notes and Communication Logs, common
language in the notes: “Youth A refused medical attention,
Youth A unwraps bandage, cleaned wounds and youth
refused medical treatment.”
• MiSACWIS Incident Reports, multiple reports of Youth A
refusing Bactrim.
• Medication Logs, Nurse went through logs and pointed out
the times Youth A refused Bactrim, which is an antibiotic to
help treat infections.
Analysis Based on interviews with Director, Therapist, Nurse, Supervisor,
Group Leader, and Youth A the facility was getting medical
treatment for Youth A’s cuts on his arm to help prevent the cuts
from getting infected. Youth A stated he would often refuse
treatment or rub substances in the wounds.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns regarding the youth's ability to self-harm to
that extent at the previous facility as well as the need for medical
treatment.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, and again on February 22, 2023, via Teams,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Director stated every youth
placed at the facility meets with Therapist to be evaluated and
then is re-evaluated as the placement continues. Director
reported there are team meetings every week to discuss the youth
at the facility and what needs to be done to make it is safe for any
of the youth. Director stated there were numerous proactive or
informal activities being done with Youth A to prevent or decrease
his self-harming behavior. Director reported Therapist,
Supervisor, Therapist 2 and himself would spend a lot of time
talking with Youth A or just hanging out with Youth A to distract
him from wanting to self-harm. Director denied staff not
intervening when Youth A self-harmed or trying to keep objects
away from him that Youth A would use to self-harm. Director
stated Youth A’s room was searched, cleared of all belongings,
moved to a different room if need be and a new bed was ordered
5

because Youth A was pulling fiberglass pieces from his bed to use
to self-harm. Director reported staff were aware of Youth A’s self-
harming behavior and would do what they could to prevent him
from cutting. Director stated Youth A is a cutter and staff can not
always stop Youth A from cutting.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, and again on February 22, 2023, via Teams,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Therapist stated Youth A
probably got more attention than any other youth in the building
because he demanded it. Therapist reported she spoke with
Youth A daily to check in on him. Therapist described Youth A
sitting in her office for extended periods of time listening to music
or coloring on multiple occasions. Therapist stated there was a
plan in place for coping skills for Youth A that included listening to
music, taking a walk with staff, or talking with staff. Therapist
stated extra checks were completed on Youth A because all the
staff knew Youth A was a cutter. Therapist reported multiple staff
spent extra time with Youth A or had Youth A shadow them while
on shift. Therapist reported Youth A was sneaky about cutting.
Therapist stated Youth A would find anything to cut with.
Therapist described Youth A using a piece of fiberglass off his bed
so he was given a different bed to sleep in, Youth A hid small
shards of glass in his bedroom so staff would vacuum the room
including the vents, Youth A broke a calculator or broke deodorant
bottle to get pieces of plastic to cut with. Therapist stated Youth
A’s room was searched daily, the room was cleared of all
belongings and then Youth A would use his fingernail to cut.
Therapist denied staff not supervising or doing the best they could
to prevent or decrease Youth A’s self-harming behavior.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on February
1, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Nurse stated she
was aware staff would clear Youth A’s room and search the room
to find anything Youth A may have hidden to use to self-harm.
Nurse stated Youth A would use his fingernail to cut and would
cover his arm, refusing to show staff. Nurse stated Bay Pines
staff completed numerous medical slips for Youth A to be
examined.
Group Leader was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Group
Leader stated Youth A had a higher level of monitoring by staff
due to Youth A’s self-harming behavior. Group Leader reported
staff did what they were supposed to do when issues came up
and took care of Youth A as much as Youth A would allow. Group
6

Leader denied having concerns staff were not trying to prevent or
decrease Youth A’s cutting.
Youth A was interviewed via Teams on February 7, 2023.
Youth A reported while at Bay Pines, “staff watched me more.”
Youth A stated he was not sure why but guessed it was because
of him cutting. Youth A described staff telling him to stop when he
was self-harming but stated he would not stop cutting. Youth A
reported staff knew of ways to calm him down and described staff
playing music, talking with him, or sitting with him. Youth A stated
staff would ask to check his arms every morning, but he did not
always show them. Youth A stated, “staff never did anything
wrong; they did what they could to help me not cut.” Youth A
stated he wanted to be done talking due to having a family phone
call in a few minutes and asked to leave the interview.
Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on February 17, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor reported more
frequent checks were completed on Youth A because staff knew
Youth A was a cutter. Supervisor described Youth A as knowing
how to get attention and often Youth A would say, “I’m gonna turn
up.” Supervisor stated these where the times Youth A would start
to self-harm. Supervisor stated Youth A was not allowed to have
any belongings in his room or on his person. Supervisor reported
Youth A would try and hide rocks in his shoe, grab a pen or pencil
off the staff desk in the pod or break something he was using to
get a piece of plastic to use to self-harm. Supervisor stated Youth
A told him he never really wanted to stop cutting. Supervisor
stated Therapist was active on the pod and would check in with
Youth A regularly. Supervisor reported many daily interactions
occurred with Youth A from the Therapist, Director, Therapist 2,
and other staff to help de-escalate Youth A. Supervisor stated
playing music and talking with staff Youth A had a connection with
as Youth A’s coping skills he would use. Supervisor reported
Youth A had a feeling chart but refused to use the chart.
Supervisor stated he felt staff did everything they could have to
prevent or decrease Youth A from self-harming.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via Teams on February 17, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Therapist 2 reported Youth
A had a safety plan that focused on Youth A using his hands for
artwork, listening to music and talking with staff. Therapist 2
reported Youth A told Therapist 2 that he likes to cut, does not
want to stop and that is what works for him to cope with his
emotions. Therapist 2 stated there were multiple nights she spent
talking with Youth A and times she spent convincing Youth A to
7

give up what item he was using to self-harm. Therapist 2
described Youth A as not having the want to stop cutting.
Therapist 2 stated self-harm is tough because there has to be the
want to stop, and for Youth A he lacked that desire. Therapist 2
stated it was not a lack of trying on staffs’ part to prevent or stop
Youth A from cutting.
Documents Reviewed:
The following documents were reviewed for Youth A from
August 2022 – January 18, 2023. There were multiple
documents from numerous dates during this time frame that
were reviewed.
• Bay Pines Center Health Service Requests completed by
Bay Pines staff requesting Youth A’s cuts to be examined
by Nurse.
• OSF HealthCare office visit notes for staff taking Youth A in
for treatment.
• OSF Walk in Clinic notes for staff taking Youth A in for
treatment.
• Staff Shift Notes and Communication Logs, common
language in the notes: “swept room, staff cleaned out room,
Therapist contacted to talk with Youth A.”
• Youth A’s Safety Plan, not dated, listed Youth A’s coping
skills as well as hygiene items being left outside his room
and staff searching Youth A’s room each night prior to bed.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as interviews with Director,
Therapist, Therapist 2, Group Leader, Supervisor, and Youth A
indicate all involved with Youth A were making numerous attempts
to prevent or decrease Youth A from self-harming. Multiple
individuals were talking with Youth A, bringing Youth A to their
office, having Youth A walk with them and providing music and art
work to help distract Youth A from wanting to self-harm.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or
Section shelter care institutions; updated treatment plan.
Description (3) The updated treatment plan shall include all of the following
information:
(c) Changes in the treatment plan, including new problems and
new goals to remedy the problems. Indicators of goal achievement
and time frames for achievement shall be specified along with a
specific behavior management plan designed to minimize
seclusion and restraint and that includes a continuum of
responses to problem behaviors.
8

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Facility did not document specific behavior management plan and
staff responses to youth's self-harming behavior.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, and again on February 22, 2023, via Teams,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Director stated there were
numerous proactive efforts and informal activities done by staff
with Youth A to prevent or decrease the self-harm behavior, but
those efforts and activities were not documented. Director
reported the communication between staff and the goals to
decrease the self-harming behavior should have been
documented. Director stated the numerous times staff talked with
Youth A or had Youth A walk around with them was not
documented.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, and again on February 22, 2023, via Teams,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Therapist stated there
were a lot of formal activities happening with Youth A that were
documented but numerous informal activities being done with
Youth A that were not documented. Therapist denied
documenting the multiple times Youth A hung out in her office
during the day as a coping mechanism.
Documents Reviewed:
The following documents were reviewed for Youth A from
August 2022 – January 18, 2023. There were multiple
documents from numerous dates during this time frame that
were reviewed.
• Bay Pines Center treatment plans for Youth A lacked a
specific behavior management plan as well as staff
responses to Youth A’s self-harming behaviors.
• Staff Shift Notes and Communication Logs, documentation
was missing describing all the efforts and activities
mentioned in the interviews during the investigation.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as multiple staff provided
input about what efforts and activities were being done to curb
Youth A’s self-harming behavior, but nothing was
formalized/required or documented in Youth A’s treatment plan.
Conclusion Violation Established
9

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4118 Social service supervisor; qualifications.
Section (1) A social service supervisor, at the time of appointment to the
Description position, shall possess either of the following:
(b) A bachelor’s degree in a human behavioral science or
another major with 25% of the credits in a human behavioral
science from an accredited college or university and 4 years of
experience as a social service worker.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff member that signed as supervisor on treatment plan is not
qualified to do so.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed via Teams on February 22, 2023, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Director verified WOC
Program Manager did not qualify to sign off on reports and
Therapist and Group Leader are now signing off on the reports.
Documents Reviewed:
• Court Report for Youth A dated 11/07/2022 and signed by
WOC Program Manager.
• WOC Program Manager’s personnel file: Did not identify
social services work experience as required.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as WOC Program Manager
does not meet the qualifications as a social services supervisor to
sign off on court reports.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement.
Section (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
Description and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility does not have a policy for self-harming behaviors.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 1, 2023, and again on February 22, 2023, via Teams,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Director reported Youth
A’s cutting, self-harming behavior was not identified as suicidal
behavior. Director stated Youth A was not on constant
observation requiring at least five-minute checks because of the
cutting. Director provided the policy for suicide precautions but a
10

policy for self-harming behaviors outlining how staff would
respond does not exist.
Documents Reviewed:
• Policy 503 – Suicide Precautions: does not address self-
harming behavior as it is not determined to be suicidal.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as there is no policy
addressing self-harming behaviors and outlining the standard
operating procedures for staff to provide care, safety, and
supervision of youth as well as methods for addressing the youth’s
needs.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2022C0114001 dated 12/02/21, CAP APPROVED 12/15/21
SIR 2021C0102007 dated 03/04/21, CAP APPROVED 03/25/21
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
